Department of Metallurgical Engineering College of Materials and Metallurgy Guizhou University Huaxi Guiyang Guizhou 550025 China Ceria is a widely known photocatalyst, to clearly understand the effects of oxygen vacancies (OVs) distribution on photocatalytic performance of ceria, surface and bulk OVs have been introduced in ceria nanorods and nanopolyhedrons. According to H2-TPR, XPS, Raman, and EPR results, P-800 (ceria nanopolyhedrons calcined at 800 °C) and R-800 (ceria nanorods calcined at 800 °C) had surface and bulk OVs and a larger OV concentration than P-500 (ceria nanopolyhedrons calcined at 500 °C) and R-500 (ceria nanorods calcined at 500 °C) which just had surface OVs, respectively. The former showed a clearly enhanced photocatalytic activity toward methylene blue (MB) and tetracycline (TC) degradation compared with the latter. After introducing surface and bulk OVs, the generated defect states in Ce 4f, metallization of ceria, and lower energy shifted density of states (DOS) co-promoted the separation of photo-excited e −/h +, which may mainly contribute to the enhancement of photocatalytic performance of P-800 and R-800. R-800 had the major active species of ·O2 −/h + to photodegrade TC, which was different from R-500 of e −/h +, due to the more negative E CB and more absorbed O2 for R-800. The synergistic effects of surface and bulk OVs were more significant for ceria nanorods than nanopolyhedrons, which may be due to the exposed facet of (110). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CeO2 Oxygen vacancies Photocatalytic Separation of photo-excited e −/h + Density functional theory (DFT) Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Photocatalysis is a promising strategy for waste water purification [1], conversion of CO2 [2] and hydrogen evolution [3,4]. Although the photocatalysis process has achieved obvious progresses, low-cost photocatalysts with efficient catalytic performance are still inspired, and previous studies have proved that ceria is one of the attracted photocatalysts [5,6]. Cerium is the most abundant rare earth element in the earth's crust [7], and thanks to its special 4f electron structure [8], ceria has an excellent redox ability. It is well known that oxygen vacancies (OVs) have significant influences on the photocatalytic performance of ceria [9,10] and have become an indispensable topic in the investigations of ceria-based photocatalysts. It is largely accepted that OVs narrow the band gap of ceria by introducing the defect states [9,11] and elevate the separation efficiency of photo-excited carriers (e −/h +) by generating small micro-domains [12] or forming e− traps [13]. However, opposite results have also been reported, e. g. the generation of more OVs in ceria lattice results in a wider band gap [14], excessively doped cations ions and formed OVs impeded the photocatalytic activity [15]. The frequently reported contradictory results require that the relationship between OVs and the physico-chemical properties of ceria need to be further clarified. The generation of OVs in ceria lattice mainly occurs in the following three ways: (i) partial reduction from ceria by chemical reducing [16], high-temperature annealing [17], and X-ray or plasma exposing [18]; (ii) doping additional elements [19,20]; and (iii) incomplete oxidization from cerium(III) compounds [21]. The formation method of OVs may affect their functions on ceria photocatalytic properties. Besides, OVs have various distributed characteristics, such as double OVs [22] and linear OVs [23], and they can be present on ceria surface [24] or bulk lattice [25], which may also influence the photo-chemical properties of ceria. Few reports in the literature focus on these effects of OVs distribution on the photocatalytic properties of ceria. However, the relevant and worthwhile investigation may offer new insights for a greater understanding of the actions of OVs on the physical and chemical properties of ceria. In this work, we carefully designed a new investigation by annealing ceria nanorods and nanopolyhedrons in H2 at different temperatures to generate surface OVs and bulk OVs. After carefully evaluating the OV distribution and avoiding other possible influences, the effects of the OV location on the photocatalytic performance of ceria were elucidated by experimental analyses together with DFT calculations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and synthesis Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 96%), cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3 ·6H2O, 99.9%), and methylene blue (MB, C16H18ClN3S) were ordered from Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China), while tetracycline (TC, C22H24N2O8) were purchased from Macklin Chemistry Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All the chemicals were used as received. Nanoceria was synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method [26], where 0.868 g cerium precursor of Ce(NO3)3 ·6H2O was dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water, and 9.6 g or 0.160 g of NaOH was added to 35 mL of deionized water, which was then dropped into the prepared cerium solution. The formed suspension was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 100 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitate was washed several times alternately with deionized water and anhydrous alcohol. The obtained powder was dried at 60 °C for 8 h and ground, and named R-CeO2 and P-CeO2, respectively, depending on whether 9.6 g or 0.160 g of NaOH was added to 35 mL of deionized water. The prepared nanoceria was then laid as a layer in an alumina boat and then placed in a tube furnace. Before calcining under hydrogen, the air in the furnace was evacuated by repeatedly charging argon and vacuuming. Then, 400 mL/min of hydrogen (88.8 kPa total pressure of Guiyang) was flowed into the furnace for calcining at 500 °C for 2 h after heating to that temperature from room temperature at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, or at 800 °C for the same amount of time after heating to 600 °C from room temperature at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and then at 5 °C/min from 600 °C to 800 °C. The calcined ceria samples were noted as P-500, P-800, R-500, and R-800, where P and R mean, respectively, P-CeO2 and R-CeO2, and the 500 and 800 represent the calcination temperature. 2.2 Materials characterizations The synthesized and calcined ceria were subjected to serval analyses. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Empyrean, Panalytical, Netherlands), TEM and HRTEM (Titan G260–300, FEI, USA) were used to characterize the phase and microstructure. H2-TPR (AutoChem II 2920, Micromeritics, USA) was used to test the reduction behavior by flowing argon mixture containing 10% hydrogen at a flow rate of 30 mL/min from room temperature to 1000 °C. Raman spectra (LabRAM HR Evolution, HORIBA, France), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Scientific K-Alpha, Thermo, USA) and Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR, EMXPLUS, Bruker, Germany) were employed to evaluate the OVs of the ceria. UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–Vis DRS, UV 2700, Shimadzu, Japan), photoluminescence spectra (PL, FluoroMax-4, HORIBA, France) with an excitation wavelength of 300 nm, and EPR were used to investigate the photochemical property. Electrochemical workstation (CHI660C, CHI Shanghai Co., China) was introduced to record the photocurrent curves and Mott-Schottky plots of prepared ceria. 2.3 Evaluation of photocatalytic performance Photocatalytic performance was evaluated by the photodegradation efficiency of MB and TC. The MB was dissolved in water, and the TC was dissolved in diluted hydrochloric acid. In a typical test, 20 mg of ceria was dispersed in 80 mL of 10 mg/L MB or TC solution by a 30 min ultrasound. After dark adsorption at 25 °C for 30 min to achieve an adsorption-desorption equilibrium, a 250 W Xeon lamp was turned on for reaction. A 5 mL solution was sampled in a 30 min interval in the following 2 h, and the MB/TC concentration was measured by a spectrophotometer with a wavelength of 664 or 357 nm. The photodegradation degree is calculated by Eq. (1). (1) Photodegradation ratio ( % ) = ( 1 − c / c 0 ) × 100 % where c and c 0 are the tested and initial concentration of MB or TC, respectively. Due to the low concentration of organic solution and weak adsorption, the photocatalytic kinetics followed the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model (L-H model) [27]: (2) ln c 0 c = k t where c and c 0 is the tested and initial concentration of MB or TC, k is the apparent rate constant, and t is the photocatalytic reaction time. In experiments to capture the active species, 0.0269 g of ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid disodium (EDTA-2Na), 0.0235 g of potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7), 7.5 µL tert‑bu-tanol (TBA), or 0.0086 g benzoquinone (BQ) was added to the TC solution to trap h +, e −, ·OH, or ·O2 −, respectively. 2.4 DFT simulation The effects of the OV distribution on CeO2 were simulated by first-principles calculation based on density functional theory (DFT), implemented in a Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) code [28]. The electron exchange and correlation were treated within the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) by using Perdew-Bruke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functionals [29], and all studied bulk systems were treated by DFT+U (U eff=5.0 eV) [30,31], to account for the coulombic interaction between Ce-4f electrons [32]. (111) plane was selected in this work based on the HRTEM images of prepared ceria. Two surface OVs (CeO2(111)−2Svac), two bulk OVs (CeO2(111)−2Bvac), and one surface with one bulk OVs (CeO2(111)-SBvac) were built as shown in Fig. S1. The K-points in the calculation of CeO2 bulk structure were set as 3 × 3 × 3, and that for the surface were set as 3 × 3 × 1. The cut-off energy of the plane wave was 520 eV, and the energy convergence standard of the simulated system was set as 10−5 eV. 3 Results 3.1 Phase and morphology characterizations TEM images of the prepared uncalcined ceria, shown in Fig. 1 , exhibit typical polyhedral particles and rod-like shapes, where the average size of the ceria nanopolyhedrons is measured as 9.51 nm, and the average length and diameter of ceria nanorods are 87.23 nm and 7.01 nm, respectively, as shown in Fig. S2. After calcining, the size of P-500 and P-800 increases, and the length of R-500 becomes slightly longer with a larger diameter while the length of R-800 decreases and the diameter increases. P-500 and R-500 have similar shapes and size distributions with the uncalcined samples, and the (111) plane is observed in P-500, while both the (111) and (100) facets are observed in R-500. After treating at 800 °C, P-800 and R-800 show a considerably sintered morphology, and the (111) plane is found in P-800, while (111) and (110) planes can be seen in R-800. Besides, many nanopores formed on the ceria nanorods after calcining in hydrogen, as shown by the nanopores marked in Fig. 1(e, f). Fig. 2 (a) displays the H2-TPR results of as-synthesized ceria, where two or three peaks are observed for the rod-like and polyhedral nanoceria samples. The reduction temperature is primarily affected by the bond energy between cerium and oxygen atom [24]. It is widely reported [33–37] that the reduction peak located below 500 °C corresponds to the reduction of the surface oxygen of ceria, while the peak appearing at a higher temperature around 800 °C represents the reduction of bulk oxygen. P-CeO2 has a distinct peak at 332.6 °C, which should be attributed to the removal of surface adsorbed oxygen, while the typical first stage of the interaction with hydrogen is around 500 °C [38]. The reducing signal peaks are found at 473.1, and 794.9 °C for P-CeO2 and 493.4 and 769.2 °C for R-CeO2, which evidences that surface OVs can be formed by annealing nanoceria at 500 °C, while both the surface OVs and bulk OVs may be generated by a high-temperature reduction at 800 °C in H2. The XRD patterns of the calcined samples are shown in Fig. 2(b), where typical diffraction patterns of ceria (PDF # 03–065–2975) are recorded [39], no diffraction peaks of Ce2O3 or cerium sub-dioxide can be observed after reduction. The ceria calcined at 800 °C has stronger diffraction intensities, suggesting a higher crystallinity [40]. The calculated crystal sizes of P-800 and R-800 are 54.5 nm and 41.1 nm, which are around 4.2 and 3.8 times larger than the 12.9 nm and 10.9 nm for P-500 and R-500, as a consequence of a higher calcining temperature. 3.2 Characterization of surface and bulk OVs The XPS results are presented in Fig. 3 . In Ce 3d, three states for Ce4+, including Ce3d94f0O2p6, Ce3d94f1O2p5, and Ce3d94f2O2p4 corresponding to Ce 3d3/2(Ce 3d5/2) are marked as u"'(v"'), u"(v") and u(v), respectively, and Ce3d94f1O2p6 and Ce3d94f2O2p5 are related to four peaks fitted as u'(v') and u 0(v 0) belonging to Ce3+ [41]. The Ce3+ percentage is calculated by Eq. (3). (3) C e 3 + concentration ( % ) = C e 3 + C e 3 + + C e 4 + × 100 % = area ( v 0 , u 0 , v ′ , u ′ ) total area × 100 % In O 1s spectra, three peaks consist of lattice oxygen (Olat, 529.5 and 527.7 eV) and adsorbed oxygen (Oads, 531.8 eV), where Oads is related to Ce3+ and OVs [42,43], and its percentage is calculated by Eq. (4) . (4) O ads concentration ( % ) = O ads O ads + O lat × 100 % = area ( O ads ) total area × 100 % As reported in related literatures [44,45], ceria annealed at a higher temperature in H2 contains more OVs, and the similar phenomenon can be detected in Fig. 3(d). P-800 (24.43% and 16.63%) and R-800 (29.42% and 18.19%) have higher Ce3+ and Oads concentrations than that of P-500 (23.29% and 16.19%) and R-500 (23.93% and 16.11%) respectively. Comparing with the increase degree of P-CeO2, the change of R-CeO2 is more obvious, which may be due to the exposed facet of (110) in R-800, where the (110) plane is regarded to be more active than the (111) plane [46,47]. XPS results are further supported by Raman spectra, as displayed in Fig. 4 (a). The F2g mode in the Raman spectra of ceria denotes the symmetrical vibration of Ce-O-Ce should be located at 466 cm−1 for pure and stoichiometric ceria [48], and the Raman downshift can be indexed to the formation of OVs, and a larger Raman downshift indicates more OVs [49]. The F2g mode for P-500, R-500, P-800, and R-800 is determined at 461.36 cm−1, 461.36 cm−1, 456.07 cm−1, and 457.83 cm−1, respectively, which means more OVs are generated in the lattice of P-800 and R-800 than that in P-500 and R-500. The EPR results, as given in Fig. 4(b), exhibit an intense symmetric signal located at around g = 2.0036, which can be ascribed to unpaired electrons in OVs [50,51]. P-800 and R-800 have a stronger symmetric signal than P-500 and R-500, indicating that more OVs are generated by annealing at 800 °C [52]. Thus, as summarized in Fig. 4(c), based on the H2-TPR, XPS, Raman, and EPR spectra, P-800 and R-800 have more total OVs than P-500 and R-500, and the OVs of P-800 and R-800 exist both on the surface and in the bulk lattice, while most of OVs distribute on the surface of P-500 and R-500. 3.3 Photocatalytic performance The photocatalytic performance towards MB and TC degradation are presented in Fig. 5 and Table 1 . All the ceria samples exhibit an excellent MB removal ability, and P-800 and R-800 have significantly higher photocatalytic activity than P-500 and R-500. The MB removal degrees of P-800 and R-800 are determined as 98.79 and 99.98% after 120 min with the calculated rates of 0.03619 and 0.07512 min−1, respectively. For TC degradation, R-800 shows the largest degradation extent of 77.30%, while P-800 exhibits 69.77%, which is higher than that of R-500 and P-500. Besides, the degradation rate with R-800 is 3.37 and 1.43 times that of R-500 toward MB and TC degradation. The results clearly indicate that both the rod-like and polyhedral ceria containing bulk and surface OVs have clearly enhanced photocatalytic performances. 4 Discussions R-800 and P-800 have a higher crystallinity and larger crystal size, which should hinder their catalytic properties [53,54]. The higher catalytic activity of these samples is related to their very different OV distribution. 4.1 Band structure analyses The UV–Vis DRS spectra and calculated band gaps are shown in Fig. 6 (a, b). Polyhedral nanoceria has a broader light absorption than ceria nanorods, while the ceria annealed at 800 °C has a slight red shift compared with that calcined at 500 °C in the same morphology. The band gap is calculated by Tauc's formula [55]: (5) ( α h v ) n = A ( h v − E g ) where α, h, v, A, and E g represent the absorption coefficient, Planck's constant, photon frequency, proportionality constant, and band gap of a semiconductor, respectively, and the value of n for CeO2 is 2 [56]. The band gaps (E g) of P-500, R-500, P-800, and R-800 are calculated as 3.00 eV, 3.16 eV, 3.14 eV, and 3.32 eV, respectively. Fig. 6(c) shows the Mott-Schottky plots, which offers information of the flat band potential. For an n-type semiconductor, the bottom of the conduction band (E CB) is about 0.1 eV lower than the flat band potential [57–59], so the E CB for P-500, R-500, P-800, and R-800 are calculated as −0.57, −0.77, −0.65, and −1.04 eV (vs. Ag/AgCI (saturated KCI)), which are equivalent to −0.37, −0.57, −0.45 and −0.84 eV (vs. NHE) [60], respectively. Then, the valence band (E VB) can be calculated by Eq. (6), and the results are listed in Table S1. (6) E VB = E CB + E g The extrapolated E CB/E VB for P-500, R-500, P-800, and R-800 is −0.37/2.63, −0.57/2.59, −0.45/2.69 and −0.84/2.48 eV, respectively. The E VB of the prepared ceria is more positive than that of E(·OH/OH−)=1.99 eV and E(·OH /H2O)=2.27 eV (vs. NHE) [61], suggesting that ·OH radicals can be generated under light excitation. Clearly, the ECB is more negative than that of E(O2/·O2 −)=−0.33 eV (vs. NHE) [62], indicating that ·O2 − can be formed during the light excitation, and the R-800 has the most negative E CB, which offer a stronger oxidation ability. 4.2 Photochemical properties The photochemical properties including PL spectra and photocurrent curves are given in Fig. 7 . P-800 and R-800 show a lower PL intensity than P-500 and R-500, indicating that they have a lower recombination of e −/h + [63]. In Fig. 7(b), P-800 and R-800 have a larger photocurrent intensity, suggesting a more efficient separation of e−/h+ [64]. 4.3 Influence on the photo-excited active species Fig. 8 (a, b) exhibit the TC degradation degrees with the capture agents for the prepared ceria nanorods, where a lower degradation extent (or larger c/c 0) compared with that without introducing an agent means that the trapped active species have effects on photocatalysis. The TC removal extents decrease after adding each capture agent, indicating that all h +, e −, ·OH, and ·O2 − contribute to the TC degradation. For R-500, after adding K2Cr2O7 and EDTA-2Na, the final c/c 0 is found as 0.8283 and 0.8029, respectively, suggesting that the surface e −/h + is more important for its photocatalytic property. Differently, it is found that ·O2 − and h + are dominant for R-800 after introducing BQ and EDTA-2Na, and the final c/c 0 is determined to be 0.7887 and 0.6752, respectively. R-800 has a more negative E CB than R-500 to produce more ·O2 −. Moreover, OVs are widely considered to benefit adsorption and create active sites [65]. R-800 owns more Oads (see Fig. 3d) and may promote the adsorption of O2, which benefits the transfer from e − to ·O2 −. The observed results reveal a new insight for the differences in the effects of OV distribution on the active photocatalytic radicals of ceria. The EPR spectra shown in Fig. 8(c, d) clearly present that after light excitation, ·OH and several ·O2 − signals are observed [26], which means that ·OH and ·O2 − free radicals are generated under light excitation. Compared with R-500 and P-500, the R-800 and P-800 have stronger peaks, meaning that more free radicals are formed. Besides, ceria nanorods generally have a stronger signal than ceria nanopolyhedrons, which agrees with the photocatalysis results. 4.4 DFT simulation results The DFT simulation results including the total density of states (TDOS) and partial density of states (PDOS) for constructed ceria (111) surfaces are displayed in Fig. 9 . The Fermi level (E f) is set at 0 eV. It can be seen that the VB and CB are mostly attributed to O 2p and Ce 4f, respectively. The CeO2(111) surface shows typical characterizations of a semiconductor with high symmetry, meaning that the CeO2(111) surface exhibits spin non-polarization [66]. In contrast, the TDOS and PDOS of CeO2(111) with OVs shift to lower energy states, which benefits the transfer of free e − of catalysts [67]. Besides, a spin splitting can be observed between VB and CB after introducing OVs, and a newly formed peak of a defect state corresponds to the Ce 4f, while the electron on it can be easily excited to CB and form a carrier e − [31], and the DOS of CeO2(111)−2Svac is found to be located at lower energy than CeO2(111)−2Bvac. The defect state area of CeO2(111)−2Bvac is larger than those of other simulated modes, which means an increase in the electron and carrier density [68]. Besides, the defect peak of CeO2(111)−2Bvac is located closer to the VB than CeO2(111)−2Svac, which makes it easier to trap low-energy electrons during the excitation from VB [69] and further enhances the separation of e −/h +. CeO2(111)-SBvac seems to have the advantages of both CeO2(111)−2Svac and CeO2(111)−2Bvac, where the DOS shifts to lower energy than CeO2(111)−2Bvac, and it has a wider defect peak and closer to VB than CeO2(111)−2Svac. Thus, the CeO2(111)-SBvac is suggested to generate photo-carriers more easily than CeO2(111)−2Bvac, and has a facilitation of e −/h + separation compared with CeO2(111)−2Svac. Simulated band structures by the DFT method are shown in Fig. 10 . The CeO2(111) surface has a calculated band gap of 2.15 eV, which is smaller than the well-accepted measured gap of ∼3.2 eV [70]. This is due to the difference between the constructed surface structure and the actual structure, as well as errors in band gap calculation in the DFT simulation [71]. CeO2(111)-SBvac has a narrower band gap of 1.09 eV compared with CeO2(111)−2Svac (1.24 eV), which is different from the UV–Vis DRS results. It can be understood considering that the narrow of band gap by introducing bulk OVs cannot offset the widened effect caused by the enlargement of crystal size (see Fig. 2b) [72]. Interestingly, the band gap of CeO2(111)−2Bvac is calculated to be 0.07 eV, which indicates that it is almost becoming conductive material and suggests that the bulk OVs boost the metallization of ceria. After introducing OVs, the band structure becomes denser, and shifts to lower energy, and the narrowed band means that the electrons are more easily excited from VB to CB to form e −/h + [73]. Meanwhile, the defect states can be noticed near the Femi level, which appears in the electronic band structure essential to electron transfer between the conduction bands to the valence bands [74], and further promotes the separation of photo-excited carriers [75]. 4.5 Mechanism of enhancement of photocatalytic properties of ceria by surface and bulk OVs Based on the discussions above, the proposed mechanism of the enhancement of photocatalytic performance of ceria by the surface and bulk OVs is summarized in Fig. 11 . After introducing the surface and bulk OVs, the energy band shifts to lower energy with a narrow band gap, which is beneficial for the formation of photo-excited e −/h + [73]. The generated defect state corresponding to the Ce 4f makes it easier for the electron on it to be easily excited to CB and form a carrier e − [31]. At the same time, the defect state can also trap the generated e −, and the metallization of the ceria with bulk OVs and the lower energy shifted DOS synergistically promote the separation efficiency of e −/h +. Besides, compared with the ceria that only contains surface OVs, CeO2 with both the surface and bulk OVs has a more negative E CB and more OVs to adsorb O2, which enhances the generation of ·O2 −. The enriched ·O2 − together with h +, as well as the assistants of e − and ·OH, further degrades the TC pollutant. On the other hand, ceria with homogenously doped additional cations [76] or formed from incomplete oxidization of Ce(III) compounds [77] were reported to have enhanced photocatalytic activities. The surface and bulk OVs of ceria may also be generated by those treatments, and the mechanism proposed in this work may provide new insights for the enhancements of photocatalytic performance. 4.6 Effects of morphology or exposed facets on photocatalytic properties of ceria Finally, to understand the influences of surface and bulk OVs on the photocatalytic properties of differently shaped ceria more clearly, the variation of Ce3+, Oads, band gap, average photo-excited current of P-500 vs. P-800 and R-500 vs. R-800 was compared in terms of the variation degree calculated by the following formula: (7) Variation degree ( % ) = X ( 800 ) − X ( 500 ) X ( 500 ) × 100 % where X means the organic degradation degree or the measured characteristics of ceria. The compared results are shown in Fig. 12 . The photodegradation degrees of MB and TC with ceria after introducing bulk OVs rose by 5.89% and 14.45% for nanorods, and 9.22% and 12.15% for nanopolyhedrons, respectively. The calculated kinetic rate (k) for nanorods increased by 237.47% and 42.75% for MB and TC degradation, respectively, which is much greater than that of nanopolyhedrons. As shown in Fig. 12(b), ceria nanorods have increased Ce3+ and Oads concentrations after annealing at 800 °C due to the appropriate increased facet activity, as mentioned before. Besides, Fig. 12(c) exhibits that R-800 has a more significantly enhanced photo-excited current than P-800 and the ceria annealed at 500 °C, as also can be seen in Fig. 7(a), which also indicates that R-800 has the lowest PL intensity. These results suggest that the bulk OVs may have a stronger influence on the separation of e −/h + in ceria nanorods than nanopolyhedrons. The possible reasons may be due to the 1D structure of ceria nanorods, where 1D nanoceria was proved to have a better separation efficiency of e −/h + [78], and offer shorter diffusion pathways [79]. 5 Conclusions In this work, the effects of OV distribution on ceria photocatalytic performance were investigated in detail. It is concluded that the ceria nanorods and nanopolyhedrons annealed at 800 °C in hydrogen contained surface and bulk OVs, and had clearly enhanced photocatalytic activities towards TC and MB degradation. P-800 and R-800 had 98.79% and 99.98% MB removal degrees after 120 min, respectively, and 69.77% and 77.30% for TC removal, which are notably higher than those of P-500 and R-500. R-800 had 3.37 and 1.43 times higher rates than R-500 toward MB and TC degradation. After introducing surface and bulk OVs, the energy band shifted to lower energy, but it cannot offset the disadvantage of the multiple growth of crystal size. The generated defect state corresponding to the Ce 4f trapped the generated e −. The metallization of ceria and lowered energy shifted DOS with surface and bulk OVs offered a transfer channel of e −, which synergistically promoted the separation efficiency of e −/h +. The average photo-current after introducing surface and bulk OVs was elevated by 28.30% and 70.28% for P-800 and R-800, respectively, which is the major factor to promote photocatalytic performance. Compared with the ceria only containing surface OVs, CeO2 with surface and bulk OVs has a greater negative E CB and adsorbed O2, which increases the generation of ·O2 − from e −, and becomes the main species for organic degradation. Besides, the surface and bulk OVs showed a stronger influence on ceria nanorods, which may be due to the exposed planes of (110). The results obtained in this work offer new insights for understanding the effects of OV distribution on the photocatalytic performances of ceria. coredata.dc:description: Ceria is a widely known photocatalyst, to clearly understand the effects of oxygen vacancies (OVs) distribution on photocatalytic performance of ceria, surface and bulk OVs have been introduced in ceria nanorods and nanopolyhedrons. According to H2-TPR, XPS, Raman, and EPR results, P-800 (ceria nanopolyhedrons calcined at 800 °C) and R-800 (ceria nanorods calcined at 800 °C) had surface and bulk OVs and a larger OV concentration than P-500 (ceria nanopolyhedrons calcined at 500 °C) and R-500 (ceria nanorods calcined at 500 °C) which just had surface OVs, respectively. The former showed a clearly enhanced photocatalytic activity toward methylene blue (MB) and tetracycline (TC) degradation compared with the latter. After introducing surface and bulk OVs, the generated defect states in Ce 4f, metallization of ceria, and lower energy shifted density of states (DOS) co-promoted the separation of photo-excited e −/h +, which may mainly contribute to the enhancement of photocatalytic performance of P-800 and R-800. R-800 had the major active species of ·O2 −/h + to photodegrade TC, which was different from R-500 of e −/h +, due to the more negative E CB and more absorbed O2 for R-800. The synergistic effects of surface and bulk OVs were more significant for ceria nanorods than nanopolyhedrons, which may be due to the exposed facet of (110).
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement effects of surface and bulk oxygen vacancies on the photocatalytic properties of ceria
